This ideal is portrayed in Tartuffe through the characterization of Orgon. Orgon wanted to believe that is he did all the things Tartuffe said that was right or wrong, he would have a life without sin. The thought of going back to eternal truths after Tartuffe left though was Dorine with a worry of the family becoming broken again. Moliere had issues with the Church before even writing the story of Tartuffe which is why I think Moliere would not agree with reasoning being the only important emphasis of this time. Sor Juana embodies the importance of reason by her relentless pursuit of equality for women. She believed that if those around her could just use reason, they would all come to one conclusion-- the eternal truth that women had value despite their gender roles. The Enlightenment period was considered a time that reformed society and was a  “decisive in the making of modernity” (White).   

    Orgon in Tartuffe was the definition of a follower. His reasoning was understanding to himself even if it meant losing his whole family. He was so mesmerized by the character of Tartuffe without even knowing him and just letting him come take over the family making everything his way. Orgon really just wanted to be a follower of God and do no harm but he was so blinded and did not believe the hypocrisy that was being performed. Orgon was seeking his eternal truth when he brought Tartuffe in with a reasoning of trying to get closer to a religion. 

    Possibly an overlooked character in Tartuffe was Dorine, a housekeeper who probably should have been more quieter than what she actually was. She had a reason to be included, all the thoughts of Tartuffe moving in was just the same as the other members of the household, of course besides Madame Pernelle who was the mother of Orgon. She did not think we needed somebody to come in to bring back a household of eternal truth. She stated “He is intoxicated with Tartuffe” (Tartuffe pg.143). There was never a point made that gave reason to why she thought Tartuffe should stay. 

     Moliere was seen as a controversial person by the public. He wrote the story Tartuffe to show reasoning was not the most important. “Moliere's questioning goes far beyond witty farce: his works suggests types but also the foolishness of trusting reason to arrange human affairs” (Tartuffe pg.135), this statement provides information about the real reason of why he chose to write Tartuffe. Even with people despising the story, he was able to target certain people and even have the support by King Louis XIV. Moliere wanted people to see that their is more importance than just reasoning and he showed by giving hypocrisy and even sarcasm.

     Logic is a correct reasoning of communication. Sor Juana had her reasoning of believing women should be allowed the same education as men. She taught herself even when others would not, for example learning how to read and write from her grandfathers library. She would show logic by not being rude or hateful, but by showing that she had wisdom and importance. It is stated in the text Sor Juana Ines De La CruzEven with her being a religious women, her stories were not always focused on that.     The search for an “eternal truth” through philosophy and reason was an identifying characteristic of the Enlightenment period. This ideal is portrayed in Tartuffe through the characterization of Orgon. Orgon wanted to believe that is he did all the things Tartuffe said that was right or wrong, he would have a life without sin. The thought of going back to eternal truths after Tartuffe left though was Dorine with a worry of the family becoming broken again. Moliere had issues with the Church before even writing the story of Tartuffe which is why I think Moliere would not agree with reasoning being the only important emphasis of this time. Sor Juana embodies the importance of reason by her relentless pursuit of equality for women. She believed that if those around her could just use reason, they would all come to one conclusion-- the eternal truth that women had value despite their gender roles. The Enlightenment period was considered a time that reformed society and was a  “decisive in the making of modernity” (White).   

    Orgon in Tartuffe was the definition of a follower. His reasoning was understanding to himself even if it meant losing his whole family. He was so mesmerized by the character of Tartuffe without even knowing him and just letting him come take over the family making everything his way. Orgon really just wanted to be a follower of God and do no harm but he was so blinded and did not believe the hypocrisy that was being performed. Orgon was seeking his eternal truth when he brought Tartuffe in with a reasoning of trying to get closer to a religion. 

    Possibly an overlooked character in Tartuffe was Dorine, a housekeeper who probably should have been more quieter than what she actually was. She had a reason to be included, all the thoughts of Tartuffe moving in was just the same as the other members of the household, of course besides Madame Pernelle who was the mother of Orgon. She did not think we needed somebody to come in to bring back a household of eternal truth. She stated “He is intoxicated with Tartuffe” (Tartuffe pg.143). There was never a point made that gave reason to why she thought Tartuffe should stay. 

     Moliere was seen as a controversial person by the public. He wrote the story Tartuffe to show reasoning was not the most important. “Moliere's questioning goes far beyond witty farce: his works suggests types but also the foolishness of trusting reason to arrange human affairs” (Tartuffe pg.135), this statement provides information about the real reason of why he chose to write Tartuffe. Even with people despising the story, he was able to target certain people and even have the support by King Louis XIV. Moliere wanted people to see that their is more importance than just reasoning and he showed by giving hypocrisy and even sarcasm.

     Logic is a correct reasoning of communication. Sor Juana had her reasoning of believing women should be allowed the same education as men. She taught herself even when others would not, for example learning how to read and write from her grandfathers library. She would show logic by not being rude or hateful, but by showing that she had wisdom and importance. It is stated in the text (Sor Juana Ines De La Cruz pg.241), “The artistry of this piece of self-defense demonstrates Sor Juana's powers and thus constitutes part of her justification”, it was never shown that Sor Juana demanded respect but was given it through her writing and becoming more than just a woman with no education. Even with her being a religious women, her stories were not always focused on that. Sor Juana was an influential person for people in the convent that she resided in and even for people past her time.  Sor Juana used logic to prove herself and the importance of being educated. 

   Sor Juana showed true emotion of a female. She showed weakness in her stories coming from a side of insecurities and issues. “While ostensibly declaring her humility and her religious subordination in the text, Sor Juana also manages to advance claims for her sex that are more far-reaching and profound than any previously offered, painting a passionate yet nuanced picture of the life of the mind that combines rhetorical precision and intense emotion”(Sor Juana Ines De La Cruz pg.240). This shows that she was never scared to show her sides of stories even if they were deep and personal. Reasoning was never enough and this is probably why she was starting to become more known and was one the first female Mexican writers. By the time her era was coming to an end, she made the one of the greatest remarks on the New World. 

    The story of Tartuffe shows the place of reasoning coming from a side of religiousness. A value of happiness was wanted by trying to achieve the goal of being Tartuffe himself. He was seen as the righteous person and Orgon believed everything would be perfect by abiding by his rules. Moliere wanted to show not everything can work out right just by going off of reasoning and the importance of trying to find happiness. Dorine was given the role of trying to prove it before it was too late even though in the end Orgon and his family got back what they had in first place. Trying to shape one another by using reasoning only would never work out in the real life. Tartuffe was the one that would get the “karma” even though he tried to abide by rules he thought was right. This relates to reasoning as a whole even if this era is considered a time of later modern times. 

    Sor Juana showed a different perspective on reasoning but by using logic and emotions.

    The search for an “eternal truth” through philosophy and reason was an identifying characteristic of the Enlightenment period. This ideal is portrayed in Tartuffe through the characterization of Orgon. Orgon wanted to believe that is he did all the things Tartuffe said that was right or wrong, he would have a life without sin. The thought of going back to eternal truths after Tartuffe left though was Dorine with a worry of the family becoming broken again. Moliere had issues with the Church before even writing the story of Tartuffe which is why I think Moliere would not agree with reasoning being the only important emphasis of this time. Sor Juana embodies the importance of reason by her relentless pursuit of equality for women. She believed that if those around her could just use reason, they would all come to one conclusion-- the eternal truth that women had value despite their gender roles. The Enlightenment period was considered a time that reformed society and was a  “decisive in the making of modernity” (White).   

    Orgon in Tartuffe was the definition of a follower. His reasoning was understanding to himself even if it meant losing his whole family. He was so mesmerized by the character of Tartuffe without even knowing him and just letting him come take over the family making everything his way. Orgon really just wanted to be a follower of God and do no harm but he was so blinded and did not believe the hypocrisy that was being performed. Orgon was seeking his eternal truth when he brought Tartuffe in with a reasoning of trying to get closer to a religion. 

    Possibly an overlooked character in Tartuffe was Dorine, a housekeeper who probably should have been more quieter than what she actually was. She had a reason to be included, all the thoughts of Tartuffe moving in was just the same as the other members of the household, of course besides Madame Pernelle who was the mother of Orgon. She did not think we needed somebody to come in to bring back a household of eternal truth. She stated “He is intoxicated with Tartuffe” (Tartuffe pg.143). There was never a point made that gave reason to why she thought Tartuffe should stay. 

     Moliere was seen as a controversial person by the public. He wrote the story Tartuffe to show reasoning was not the most important. “Moliere's questioning goes far beyond witty farce: his works suggests types but also the foolishness of trusting reason to arrange human affairs” (Tartuffe pg.135), this statement provides information about the real reason of why he chose to write Tartuffe. Even with people despising the story, he was able to target certain people and even have the support by King Louis XIV. Moliere wanted people to see that their is more importance than just reasoning and he showed by giving hypocrisy and even sarcasm.

     Logic is a correct reasoning of communication. Sor Juana had her reasoning of believing women should be allowed the same education as men. She taught herself even when others would not, for example learning how to read and write from her grandfathers library. She would show logic by not being rude or hateful, but by showing that she had wisdom and importance. It is stated in the text (Sor Juana Ines De La Cruz pg.241), “The artistry of this piece of self-defense demonstrates Sor Juana's powers and thus constitutes part of her justification”, it was never shown that Sor Juana demanded respect but was given it through her writing and becoming more than just a woman with no education. Even with her being a religious women, her stories were not always focused on that. Sor Juana was an influential person for people in the convent that she resided in and even for people past her time.  Sor Juana used logic to prove herself and the importance of being educated. 

   Sor Juana showed true emotion of a female. She showed weakness in her stories coming from a side of insecurities and issues. “While ostensibly declaring her humility and her religious subordination in the text, Sor Juana also manages to advance claims for her sex that are more far-reaching and profound than any previously offered, painting a passionate yet nuanced picture of the life of the mind that combines rhetorical precision and intense emotion”(Sor Juana Ines De La Cruz pg.240). This shows that she was never scared to show her sides of stories even if they were deep and personal. Reasoning was never enough and this is probably why she was starting to become more known and was one the first female Mexican writers. By the time her era was coming to an end, she made the one of the greatest remarks on the New World. 

    The story of Tartuffe shows the place of reasoning coming from a side of religiousness. A value of happiness was wanted by trying to achieve the goal of being Tartuffe himself. He was seen as the righteous person and Orgon believed everything would be perfect by abiding by his rules. Moliere wanted to show not everything can work out right just by going off of reasoning and the importance of trying to find happiness. Dorine was given the role of trying to prove it before it was too late even though in the end Orgon and his family got back what they had in first place. Trying to shape one another by using reasoning only would never work out in the real life. Tartuffe was the one that would get the “karma” even though he tried to abide by rules he thought was right. This relates to reasoning as a whole even if this era is considered a time of later modern times. 

    Sor Juana showed a different perspective on reasoning but by using logic and emotions. Logically, she was smart at such a young age which I think is what helped her achieve so much. Her emotional side grabbed attention of readers including myself. Her place of reason during this era showing the issues that had happened with females not getting the same attention as males. Faith was important to her and while she did struggle falling off of her faith in her stories, it never changed who she was as a person shown in. Neither of these stories sound like they came from a period of reasoning. Both of them give the same thoughts but just in different ways of thinking.
